<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EDUCATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/harvard-princeton-announce-reopening-plans?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
ECON 101 Can’t Stay on Zoom Forever
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Socially distanced education " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNjQ1L3NvY2lhbGx5X2Rpc3RhbmNlZF9lZHVjYXRpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Of universities that have released plans for the upcoming academic year, 60% are still planning to welcome students <a href="https://www.chronicle.com/article/Here-s-a-List-of-Colleges-/248626?cid=wcontentgrid_hp_1b&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">in-person</a>, according to the Chronicle of Higher Education. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">What that'll look like: </strong></span><span>Regular COVID-19 testing, smaller classes, extra cleaning, emptier dorms, students clearing out before Thanksgiving, and an opportunity to slap logos and mascots on protective gear. Well, maybe not UC Santa Cruz.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As for the others, 23% are opting for a hybrid model, 8% of schools are going fully online, and the rest are still figuring it out.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The Ivies weigh in</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Princeton and the Harvard of eastern MA finally released their plans. Princeton will welcome back roughly <a href="https://fall2020.princeton.edu/news/princeton-announces-plan-fall-2020-guidelines-undergraduates-returning-campus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">half of undergrads</a> each semester, hold most classes online, and reduce tuition 10%. Because that’s not exclusive enough, Harvard's bringing back up to <a href="https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2020/07/harvard-to-bring-up-to-40-of-undergrads-to-campus-this-fall/?utm_source=twitter&utm_campaign=hu-twitter-general&utm_medium=social&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">40% of undergrads</a> this fall. All courses are remote...but tuition’s not changing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Cornell is <a href="https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2020/07/01/cornell-researchers-say-person-semester-university-safer-online-one?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moving ahead</a> with a fully in-person semester after university researchers found that an online semester would result in <em>more</em> COVID-19 cases. Their reasoning: If classes go remote, ~9,000 students will still return to Ithaca, but the school won't be able to enforce testing and social distancing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Plans can change. </strong>After greenlighting in-person classes, USC <a href="https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-07-02/usc-will-move-most-undergraduate-classes-online-cancels-reopening?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reversed course</a> last week as California grapples with rising COVID-19 cases. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">If you think students are grumpy...</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Professors and instructors are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/03/us/coronavirus-college-professors.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushing back</a> on plans for in-person classes. Many fear that bringing students back too quickly puts them and their families at risk. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More than 800 Georgia Tech faculty members <a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/07/05/887471299/a-nightmare-georgia-tech-faculty-push-back-against-in-person-reopening-plans?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">criticized</a> the state university system for a reopening plan that makes mask-wearing optional (a policy at odds with most top public universities). Last month, 1,100 Penn State faculty members petitioned for the right to bar students from classrooms if they don't wear masks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> A few weeks ago, colleges might have felt more optimistic about fall reopenings. But after watching COVID-19 cases rise the last few weeks, the fall semester—and the fate of fragile college town economies—is looking more uncertain. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">+ Go deeper on <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/higher-ed-will-never?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">how COVID-19 has affected higher ed</a>.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/us-government-releases-ppp-data-loan-recipients?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
U.S. Government Blinks in PPP Staring Contest
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Blink" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=505 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/uSXTDFYDWpelW/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Blink" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/uSXTDFYDWpelW/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the Trump administration <a href="https://sba.app.box.com/s/tvb0v5i57oa8gc6b5dcm9cyw7y2ms6pp?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released data</a> on companies that secured Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans worth more than $150,000. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Even if incomplete, it was a highly awaited data dump after Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin initially resisted calls to make the info public.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Your PPP <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/06/us/ppp-small-business-loans.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fast facts</a>:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Treasury Department and SBA have issued 4.9 million loans totalling $521+ billion since the relief program launched in March.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The average loan size was $107,000. 86.5% of loans were for <$150,000. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>About $38.5 billion in loans were returned by the end of May.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The PPP was designed to help keep workers on payrolls, and the government claims it's <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/06/coronavirus-stimulus-list-of-ppp-small-business-loan-recipients-released.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">done just that</a>, supporting 51 million jobs through the crisis. But when you allocate $521 billion...Congress and watchdogs will try to uncover any shenanigans. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the PPP is still active. This weekend, President Trump extended the program, which still has nearly $132 billion in its coffers, until Aug. 8. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ For more on PPP, </strong>our <em>Business Casual </em>podcast digs into the program with a new episode out today. <a href="http://businesscasual.fm/latest?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Listen here</a>. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD DELIVERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/food-delivery-landscape-consolidates-uber-buys-postmates?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Uber Finds a New Best Mate
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After it seemed like Uber's acquisition of a food delivery company was going to be forever stuck five minutes away, the ride-sharing giant announced a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-postmates-m-a-uber/uber-scoops-up-postmates-for-2-65-billion-in-food-delivery-push-idUSKBN2471GQ?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">takeover of Postmates</a> yesterday in an all-stock deal worth $2.7 billion.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Food delivery is consolidating</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In June, Grubhub was <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/10/just-eat-takeaway-close-buying-grubhub?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">snapped up</a> for $7.3 billion by European delivery service Just Eat Takeaway, much to the disappointment of...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Uber, whose bid for Grubhub was hamstrung by looming regulatory scrutiny.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The competition: </strong>In February, Morgan Stanley <a href="https://www.morganstanley.com/ideas/food-delivery-app-profits#:~:text=The%20total%20addressable%20market%20for,possibly%20%24470%20billion%20by%202025.?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">estimated</a> the size of the U.S. food delivery market at $350 billion. But here's how it breaks down by market share based on May sales, per Second Measure: </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>DoorDash: 44%</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Grubhub: 23%</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Uber Eats: 23%</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Postmates: 8%</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Other: 2%</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Only <a href="https://secondmeasure.com/datapoints/food-delivery-services-grubhub-uber-eats-doordash-postmates/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">12% of Uber Eats customers</a> also used Postmates in Q1, which means Uber could capture customers it was previously missing out on. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here:</strong> Check out Brew writer Jamie Wilde's breakdown of why <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/22/no-winners-delivery-app-food-fight?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">almost no one</a> makes money in the food delivery game.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY THE MOTLEY FOOL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
804% Is a Lot of Percents
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/this-stock-could-be-like-buying-amazon-in-1997/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210100&psource=esamnbwdg0210100&wsource=esamnbwdg0210100&testId=sa-earlybird&cellId=11&campaign=sa-early-bird" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="The Motley Fool" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL3BsYWNlbWVudC9pbWFnZXMvMTAzOC8xNTkzNjk5ODg0LVBlb3BsZS02OC5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJjb21ldC1tb3JuaW5nYnJldyIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">TBH, we didn’t even know percents went that high. And while that number seems like the odds we’ll be ordering tacos for one, it actually signifies <a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/this-stock-could-be-like-buying-amazon-in-1997/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210100&psource=esamnbwdg0210100&wsource=esamnbwdg0210100&testId=sa-earlybird&cellId=11&campaign=sa-early-bird" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the returns</a> on a stock that Motley Fool co-founder David Gardner has made since he recommended it. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And this isn’t David’s first investing rodeo. He’s been an early investor in companies like <strong style="color:#000">Netflix</strong> (up 26,090%), <strong style="color:#000">Nvidia</strong> (up 2,363%), and <strong style="color:#000">Priceline.com</strong> (up 6,896%). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Those are some serious credentials, and he’s offering up his best picks only to <a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/this-stock-could-be-like-buying-amazon-in-1997/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210100&psource=esamnbwdg0210100&wsource=esamnbwdg0210100&testId=sa-earlybird&cellId=11&campaign=sa-early-bird" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">members of Motley Fool Stock Advisor</a> service. So if you’re interested in learning about David’s latest pick (and getting access to his future ones), make sure to <a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/this-stock-could-be-like-buying-amazon-in-1997/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210100&psource=esamnbwdg0210100&wsource=esamnbwdg0210100&testId=sa-earlybird&cellId=11&campaign=sa-early-bird" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sign up today</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We’re 804% sure you’ll be <a href="https://www.fool.com/ext-content/this-stock-could-be-like-buying-amazon-in-1997/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210100&psource=esamnbwdg0210100&wsource=esamnbwdg0210100&testId=sa-earlybird&cellId=11&campaign=sa-early-bird" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">glad you did</a>.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/judge-orders-shutdown-dakota-access-pipeline?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What’s $3.8 Billion, 1,172-Miles Long, and Shut Down?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Pipeline protest in North Dakota" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNjQ3L3BpcGVsaW5lX3Byb3Rlc3RfaW5fbm9ydGhfZGFrb3RhLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Scott Olson/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Dakota Access pipeline. Yesterday, U.S. District Judge James Boasberg ordered the controversial pipeline to <a href="https://apnews.com/be393de49dae81a2198ef30976212290?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shut down</a> pending a review. According to the ruling, the Army Corps of Engineers failed to complete a thorough environmental impact review, so it must halt the flow of oil within 30 days.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The pipeline starts in shale oil fields in northwest North Dakota and can transport 570,000 barrels a day to a terminal in Illinois.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in North Dakota has been a fierce critic of the pipeline, arguing an oil leak could damage the water supply and pollute sacred sites. You might remember the 2016–17 protests that captured national attention.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Advocates of the pipeline, which include the Trump administration, say it's a moneymaker for the states, counties, and tribal governments it passes through. If it stops for good, there would be billions lost in tax revenue and royalties. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Since the start of 2020, four major oil pipeline projects have either been sidelined or canceled, if you include Dakota Access. Next in the crosshairs? The <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/demise-gas-project-shows-u-113000532.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Keystone XL</a> is sure to be a hot topic come election time.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/disney-colin-kaepernick-sign-production-partnership?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Disney Drafts Kaepernick
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Disney’s ESPN <a href="https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/29417850/colin-kaepernick-disney-announce-partnership-deal?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced a partnership</a> with Colin Kaepernick’s production company, Ra Vision Media. First thing on tap is an exclusive documentary series about how the former 49ers QB became a prominent civil rights activist.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>America might feel like it just arrived at a pivotal juncture in the fight against racial injustice, but Kaepernick’s been waiting there <a href="https://www.gq.com/story/colin-kaepernick-will-not-be-silenced?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">since 2017</a>. Disney, ESPN’s parent, is bringing him on to have conversations around race, sports, and culture and to tell stories about Black and brown communities. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Kaepernick will produce other scripted and unscripted features about race and social injustice, with a focus on featuring directors and producers of color. A big task...but at least he won’t have to worry about distribution.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Disney’s unrivaled brand portfolio is at his disposal, including Hulu, Pixar, Walt Disney Television, and The Undefeated. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here...</strong>with Friday's release of <em>Hamilton</em>, the Disney+ app saw a 74% <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/hamilton-disney-plus-premiere-app-downloads-72-percent-1234698795/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increase in U.S. downloads</a> over the holiday weekend compared to the average of four weekends in June.</p>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Brew’s grammar impresario <a href="https://twitter.com/ElizaCarter34?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Eliza Carter</a> is back<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>to teach you a thing or two about how to write better.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today’s edition of the Brew’s vaunted <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/morning-brew-style-blog-4-get-lines-line?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Style Blog</a> is all about understanding those dashes that show up between words. Or is it hyphens? No clue, but we’re about to find out by reading the piece. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Eliza also digs into why Morning Brew decided to capitalize the word Black when referring to a racial, ethnic, or cultural identity. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/06/morning-brew-style-blog-4-get-lines-line?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Don’t miss it</a>.</p>

Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOf universities that have released plans for the upcoming academic year, 60% are still planning to welcome students \u003ca href=\"https://www.chronicle.com/article/Here-s-a-List-of-Colleges-/248626?cid=wcontentgrid_hp_1b\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ein-person\u003c/a\u003e, according to the Chronicle of Higher Education. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat that'll look like: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRegular COVID-19 testing, smaller classes, extra cleaning, emptier dorms, students clearing out before Thanksgiving, and an opportunity to slap logos and mascots on protective gear. Well, maybe not UC Santa Cruz.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs for the others, 23% are opting for a hybrid model, 8% of schools are going fully online, and the rest are still figuring it out.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe Ivies weigh in\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Princeton and the Harvard of eastern MA finally released their plans. Princeton will welcome back roughly \u003ca href=\"https://fall2020.princeton.edu/news/princeton-announces-plan-fall-2020-guidelines-undergraduates-returning-campus?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehalf of undergrads\u003c/a\u003e each semester, hold most classes online, and reduce tuition 10%. Because that’s not exclusive enough, Harvard's bringing back up to \u003ca href=\"https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2020/07/harvard-to-bring-up-to-40-of-undergrads-to-campus-this-fall/?utm_source=twitter\u0026utm_campaign=hu-twitter-general\u0026utm_medium=social\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e40% of undergrads\u003c/a\u003e this fall. All courses are remote...but tuition’s not changing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCornell is \u003ca href=\"https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2020/07/01/cornell-researchers-say-person-semester-university-safer-online-one?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emoving ahead\u003c/a\u003e with a fully in-person semester after university researchers found that an online semester would result in \u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e COVID-19 cases. Their reasoning: If classes go remote, ~9,000 students will still return to Ithaca, but the school won't be able to enforce testing and social distancing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePlans can change. \u003c/strong\u003eAfter greenlighting in-person classes, USC \u003ca href=\"https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-07-02/usc-will-move-most-undergraduate-classes-online-cancels-reopening?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereversed course\u003c/a\u003e last week as California grapples with rising COVID-19 cases. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIf you think students are grumpy...\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eProfessors and instructors are \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/03/us/coronavirus-college-professors.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushing back\u003c/a\u003e on plans for in-person classes. Many fear that bringing students back too quickly puts them and their families at risk. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMore than 800 Georgia Tech faculty members \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/07/05/887471299/a-nightmare-georgia-tech-faculty-push-back-against-in-person-reopening-plans?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecriticized\u003c/a\u003e the state university system for a reopening plan that makes mask-wearing optional (a policy at odds with most top public universities). Last month, 1,100 Penn State faculty members petitioned for the right to bar students from classrooms if they don't wear masks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e A few weeks ago, colleges might have felt more optimistic about fall reopenings. But after watching COVID-19 cases rise the last few weeks, the fall semester—and the fate of fragile college town economies—is looking more uncertain. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the Trump administration \u003ca href=\"https://sba.app.box.com/s/tvb0v5i57oa8gc6b5dcm9cyw7y2ms6pp?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased data\u003c/a\u003e on companies that secured Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans worth more than $150,000. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEven if incomplete, it was a highly awaited data dump after Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin initially resisted calls to make the info public.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYour PPP \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/06/us/ppp-small-business-loans.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efast facts\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Treasury Department and SBA have issued 4.9 million loans totalling $521+ billion since the relief program launched in March.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe average loan size was $107,000. 86.5% of loans were for \u003c$150,000. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAbout $38.5 billion in loans were returned by the end of May.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe PPP was designed to help keep workers on payrolls, and the government claims it's \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/06/coronavirus-stimulus-list-of-ppp-small-business-loan-recipients-released.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edone just that\u003c/a\u003e, supporting 51 million jobs through the crisis. But when you allocate $521 billion...Congress and watchdogs will try to uncover any shenanigans. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe PPP is still active. This weekend, President Trump extended the program, which still has nearly $132 billion in its coffers, until Aug. 8. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Dakota Access pipeline. Yesterday, U.S. District Judge James Boasberg ordered the controversial pipeline to \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/be393de49dae81a2198ef30976212290?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshut down\u003c/a\u003e pending a review. According to the ruling, the Army Corps of Engineers failed to complete a thorough environmental impact review, so it must halt the flow of oil within 30 days.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe pipeline starts in shale oil fields in northwest North Dakota and can transport 570,000 barrels a day to a terminal in Illinois.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Standing Rock Sioux Tribe in North Dakota has been a fierce critic of the pipeline, arguing an oil leak could damage the water supply and pollute sacred sites. You might remember the 2016–17 protests that captured national attention.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAdvocates of the pipeline, which include the Trump administration, say it's a moneymaker for the states, counties, and tribal governments it passes through. If it stops for good, there would be billions lost in tax revenue and royalties. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eSince the start of 2020, four major oil pipeline projects have either been sidelined or canceled, if you include Dakota Access. Next in the crosshairs?
